document.name: Noël_Coward
document.text:
By the end of the 1960s, Coward suffered from arteriosclerosis and, during the run of ''Suite in Three Keys'', he struggled with bouts of memory loss.Hoare, p. 501 This also affected his work in ''The Italian Job'', and he retired from acting immediately afterwards.Lesley, p. 454 He died at his home in Jamaica on 26 March 1973 of heart failure and was buried three days later on the brow of Firefly Hill, Jamaica, overlooking the north coast of the island. A memorial service was held in St. Martin-in-the-Fields in London on 29 May 1973, for which the Poet Laureate, John Betjeman, wrote and delivered a poem in Coward's honour,"We are all here today to thank the Lord for the life of Noel Coward.Noel with two dots over the 'e'And the firm decided downward stroke of the 'l'.We can all see him in our mind's eyeAnd in our mind's earWe can hear the clipped decided voice". (Lesley, p. 481) John Gielgud and Laurence Olivier read verse and Yehudi Menuhin played Bach. On 28 March 1984 a memorial stone was unveiled by the Queen Mother in Poets' Corner, Westminster Abbey. Thanked by Coward's partner, Graham Payn, for attending, the Queen Mother replied, "I came because he was my friend."Day (2007), p. 725
Coward was knighted in 1969 and was elected a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edn, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 12 March 2009. Also available in print as ''Who Was Who'' Vol. VII (1971–1980), A & C Black, 1990. ISBN 9780713632279. He received a Tony Award for lifetime achievement.Chronology accessed 27 August 2008
The Noël Coward Theatre in St Martin's Lane, originally opened in 1903 as the New Theatre and later called the Albery, was renamed in his honour after extensive refurbishment, re-opening on 1 June 2006. A statue of Coward was unveiled by the Queen Mother in the foyer of the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1998. BBC news, 8 December 1998, accessed 8 February 2009 There are also sculptures of Coward displayed in New York and Jamaica., The Noël Coward Society, accessed 10 March 2009 and , GlobalGayz.com, accessed 10 March 2009 In 2008 an exhibition devoted to Coward was mounted at the National Theatre in London.Byrne, Ciar. ''The Independent'', 21 January 2008, accessed on 17 March 2009
